verses.text: Do not let your hearts be troubled. Believe in God; believe also in Me.
verses.comment: Jesus reassures His disciples to have faith both in God and in Himself—a powerful hint at his divine identity, emphasized throughout John (cf. John 1:1, 10:30).

verses.text: In My Father’s house are many rooms. If it were not so, would I have told you that I go to prepare a place for you?
verses.comment: The reference to 'many rooms' highlights God’s generosity and the promise of eternal life. Jesus preparing a place implies ongoing, personal mediation on behalf of believers.

verses.text: And if I go and prepare a place for you, I will come again and take you to Myself, that where I am you may be also.
verses.comment: This is a strong promise of Jesus’ return and our union with Him—foundational for the hope of resurrection and eternal life.

verses.text: And you know the way to where I am going.
verses.comment: Jesus asserts the disciples’ knowledge, yet this prompts questions that allow Him to clarify His unique role.

verses.text: Thomas said to Him, "Lord, we do not know where You are going. How can we know the way?"
verses.comment: Thomas’ question underscores the disciples’ confusion and sets up Jesus’ clear declaration in the next verse.

verses.text: Jesus said to him, "I am the way, and the truth, and the life. No one comes to the Father except through Me."
verses.comment: Jesus’ exclusive claim signals His divinity and mediating role—fulfilling Old Testament prophecy pointing to the Messiah as the only path to God (cf. Isa. 35:8).

verses.text: If you had known Me, you would have known My Father also. From now on, you do know Him and have seen Him.
verses.comment: Jesus tightly links knowledge of Himself with knowledge of God—a declaration of His unity with the Father.

verses.text: Philip said to Him, "Lord, show us the Father, and that will be enough for us."
verses.comment: Philip echoes Moses’ ancient request to behold God’s glory—demonstrating the human desire for direct experience of the divine.

verses.text: Jesus said to him, "Have I been with you so long, and you still do not know Me, Philip? Whoever has seen Me has seen the Father. How can you say, ‘Show us the Father’?
verses.comment: Here, Jesus reveals Himself as the visible image of God—an explicit claim to divinity, foreshadowed in the Old Testament (cf. Isa. 9:6).

verses.text: Do you not believe that I am in the Father and the Father is in Me? The words I say to you I do not speak on My own authority, but the Father who dwells in Me does His works.
verses.comment: Jesus shows perfect communion with the Father, making His words and works a direct revelation of God.

verses.text: Believe Me that I am in the Father and the Father is in Me, or else believe because of the works themselves.
verses.comment: Even if the disciples cannot fully grasp the mystery, Jesus invites belief based on His miraculous works.

verses.text: Truly, truly, I say to you, whoever believes in Me will also do the works that I do, and greater works than these he will do, because I am going to the Father.
verses.comment: Jesus extends His mission to the disciples, promising that through His ascension and their union with Him, they will accomplish even greater things by the Spirit.

verses.text: And whatever you ask in My Name, this I will do, that the Father may be glorified in the Son.
verses.comment: Prayer in Jesus’ Name is effectual because Christ is the mediating High Priest, giving believers access to the Father.

verses.text: If you ask Me anything in My Name, I will do it.
verses.comment: Jesus again affirms personal involvement and divine authority in answering prayers—consistent with His divinity.

verses.text: If you love Me, you will keep My commandments.
verses.comment: Love for Jesus is inseparable from obedience—a call to live out faith through concrete actions, not just belief.

verses.text: And I will ask the Father, and He will give you another Helper, to be with you forever.
verses.comment: The promised 'Helper' (the Holy Spirit) continues Jesus’ presence spiritually, a divine gift promising guidance and comfort to the Church for all ages.

verses.text: Even the Spirit of truth, whom the world cannot receive, because it neither sees Him nor knows Him. You know Him, for He dwells with you and will be in you.
verses.comment: The Spirit’s indwelling sets believers apart, marking authentic Christian identity and spiritual union. Notice the personal pronoun ‘He’, emphasizing the Spirit as a Person, not a force.

verses.text: I will not leave you as orphans; I will come to you.
verses.comment: Jesus reassures the disciples of His continued presence—fulfilled both through the Spirit and, ultimately, at His second coming.

verses.text: Yet a little while and the world will see Me no more, but you will see Me. Because I live, you also will live.
verses.comment: The promise of resurrection life is a central tenet—the disciples will know the living Christ, and share in His life.

verses.text: On that day you will know that I am in My Father, and you in Me, and I in you.
verses.comment: A profound mystery: union with Christ and the Father becomes the destiny of believers, echoing later teachings about the mystical body of Christ.

verses.text: Whoever has My commandments and keeps them, he it is who loves Me. And whoever loves Me will be loved by My Father, and I will love him and reveal Myself to him.
verses.comment: Obedience is the sign of true love; Christ promises a deeper revelation for those who are faithful, echoing themes of spiritual growth through grace.

verses.text: Judas (not Iscariot) said to Him, "Lord, how is it that You will reveal Yourself to us, and not to the world?"
verses.comment: This question highlights the distinction between those granted spiritual insight and those who do not believe.

verses.text: Jesus answered him, "If anyone loves Me, he will keep My word, and My Father will love him, and We will come to him and make Our home with him."
verses.comment: This mutual indwelling suggests the abiding presence of God with faithful believers, reminiscent of the Lord’s presence in the tabernacle (cf. Ex. 25:8).

verses.text: Whoever does not love Me does not keep My words. And the word that you hear is not Mine but the Father’s who sent Me.
verses.comment: Rejection of Jesus’ teaching is rejection of God—the Son’s authority is the Father’s authority.

verses.text: I have spoken these things to you while I am still with you.
verses.comment: Jesus prepares them for a change—His earthly ministry is coming to a close.

verses.text: But the Helper, the Holy Spirit, whom the Father will send in My Name, He will teach you all things and bring to your remembrance everything that I have said to you.
verses.comment: Divine guidance is entrusted to the Spirit, ensuring that the truth of Christ’s teaching continues in the Church through all generations.

verses.text: Peace I leave with you; My peace I give to you. I do not give to you as the world gives. Do not let your hearts be troubled, neither let them be afraid.
verses.comment: The peace that Jesus imparts is supernatural—a fruit of the Spirit and reconciliation with God, distinct from worldly security.

verses.text: You heard Me say to you, ‘I am going away, and I will come to you.’ If you loved Me, you would rejoice because I am going to the Father, for the Father is greater than I.
verses.comment: ‘The Father is greater than I’ refers to the incarnate Son’s humility in the flesh, not a denial of His divinity, as clarified elsewhere (cf. John 1:1; Phil. 2:6–8).

verses.text: And now I have told you before it happens, so that when it does happen you may believe.
verses.comment: Jesus’ prophetic foresight authenticates His identity and strengthens faith—fulfilling the pattern of prophecy in the Old Testament.

verses.text: I will not speak much with you any longer, for the ruler of this world is coming. He has no power over Me.
verses.comment: ‘Ruler of this world’ refers to Satan; Christ’s victory is certain, as He remains sinless and untouchable by evil.

verses.text: But I do as the Father has commanded Me, so that the world may know that I love the Father. Rise, let us go from here.
verses.comment: Jesus’ perfect obedience reveals His love for the Father and models discipleship. The shift to action inaugurates the hour of His Passion, echoing themes of sacrificial love and mission.
